articles.headline: Would-Be Carmakers Tap the Wisdom, and Dollars, of Crowds
articles.snippet: Start-up vehicle companies, often using quirky designs, are turning to crowdfunding to finance their challenges to the established automakers.
articles.abstract: Start-up vehicle companies, often using quirky designs, are turning to crowdfunding to finance their challenges to the established automakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: AFTER Ford Motor came close to bankruptcy in the late 1970s, the company decided to bet the store on what was then a radical new design: what would come to be known as the Ford Taurus.

articles.headline: Obama Strikes Back at Russia for Election Hacking
articles.snippet: The Obama administration said it was tossing out 35 intelligence operatives and imposing sanctions on Russian intelligence services and officers.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration said it was tossing out 35 intelligence operatives and imposing sanctions on Russian intelligence services and officers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama struck back at Russia on Thursday for its efforts to influence the 2016 election, ejecting 35 suspected Russian intelligence operatives from the United States and imposing sanctions on Russia’s two leading intelligence services.

articles.headline: How Russia Recruited Elite Hackers for Its Cyberwar
articles.snippet: The government scouted a wide range of civilian programmers in recent years, even criminals, while expanding its cyberwarfare abilities.
articles.abstract: The government scouted a wide range of civilian programmers in recent years, even criminals, while expanding its cyberwarfare abilities.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Aleksandr B. Vyarya thought his job was to defend people from cyberattacks — until, he says, his government approached him with a request to do the opposite.

articles.headline: Takata Said to Be Close to Deal With U.S. Over Deadly Airbags
articles.snippet: The airbag maker is nearing a settlement with prosecutors over airbags that have been linked to deaths and injuries, according to two people briefed on the matter.
articles.abstract: The airbag maker is nearing a settlement with prosecutors over airbags that have been linked to deaths and injuries, according to two people briefed on the matter.
articles.lead_paragraph: The auto parts maker Takata is nearing a sweeping settlement with federal prosecutors over airbags that can violently explode, according to two people briefed on the discussions. The devices have been linked to many deaths and injuries and prompted the largest recall in automotive history.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Ben Protess

articles.headline: After Belt Tightening, Venture Capitalists See More Promise in 2017
articles.snippet: Money into start-ups tapered off in 2016, as did the number of deals struck. But venture capitalists are poised to invest big in start-ups and I.P.O.s in the new year.
articles.abstract: Money into start-ups tapered off in 2016, as did the number of deals struck. But venture capitalists are poised to invest big in start-ups and I.P.O.s in the new year.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Investors who once poured money into the nation’s start-ups with abandon began to tighten their belts this year.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: China Builds Out the Air as Frustrations Mount Below
articles.snippet: A new $12 billion Beijing airport is the country’s latest attempt to unclog its crowded airways — and aid its slowing economy to boot.
articles.abstract: A new $12 billion Beijing airport is the country’s latest attempt to unclog its crowded airways — and aid its slowing economy to boot.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — An angry mob ransacks a terminal. A frustrated passenger tries to leave the plane while it taxis. A pilot, who has had it up to here, advises fliers to leave the plane and mill about the tarmac — and they do.

articles.headline: Two Russian Compounds, Caught Up in History’s Echoes
articles.snippet: East Coast retreats for diplomats were seen by the Obama administration as beachside spy nests, and all Russians were ordered out.
articles.abstract: East Coast retreats for diplomats were seen by the Obama administration as beachside spy nests, and all Russians were ordered out.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A pair of luxurious waterfront compounds outside New York and Washington have for decades been a retreat for Russian diplomats, places to frolic in the water, play tennis and take lengthy steam baths.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: In a Brutal Year in Venezuela, Even Crime Fighters Are Killers
articles.snippet: The deaths of people arrested in anti-crime raids point to an alarming aspect in the wave of violence gripping the nation.
articles.abstract: The deaths of people arrested in anti-crime raids point to an alarming aspect in the wave of violence gripping the nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — The soldiers barged into Rafael González’s home as his mother and girlfriend looked on. It would be a routine questioning, they assured him and others arrested that night, before hauling them off to a dark military barracks.

articles.headline: Join Our Board: Companies Hotly Pursue New Wave of Women in Tech
articles.snippet: Even in Silicon Valley, where talent wars are legion, courting female executives to join tech company boards is particularly cutthroat.
articles.abstract: Even in Silicon Valley, where talent wars are legion, courting female executives to join tech company boards is particularly cutthroat.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For months, technology companies have pursued Amy Chang.

articles.headline: Vladimir Putin Won’t Expel U.S. Diplomats as Russian Foreign Minister Urged
articles.snippet: In a head-spinning turn, Mr. Putin decided against actions recommended just hours earlier by Sergey V. Lavrov in response to American sanctions and expulsions.
articles.abstract: In a head-spinning turn, Mr. Putin decided against actions recommended just hours earlier by Sergey V. Lavrov in response to American sanctions and expulsions.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia announced Friday that he would not retaliate against President Obama’s decision to expel Russian diplomats and impose new sanctions — only hours after his foreign minister recommended doing just that.

articles.headline: Theresa May Scolds Kerry for Focus on Israel Settlements
articles.snippet: The comments from the British leader, who has been trying to make inroads with the incoming Trump administration, represented an extraordinary public rebuke.
articles.abstract: The comments from the British leader, who has been trying to make inroads with the incoming Trump administration, represented an extraordinary public rebuke.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Even the so-called special relationship is subject to limits, it seems.

articles.headline: A Voice of Christmas Past Returns, Asking for a Hippopotamus
articles.snippet: A Postal Service ad has revived interest in a 1953 Christmas novelty hit by the former child star Gayla Peevey. (She did get the hippopotamus.)
articles.abstract: A Postal Service ad has revived interest in a 1953 Christmas novelty hit by the former child star Gayla Peevey. (She did get the hippopotamus.)
articles.lead_paragraph: This year’s holiday advertising campaign for the United States Postal Service featured a little girl’s stunningly infectious musical plea: “I Want a Hippopotamus for Christmas.” (And, as she explains, “Only a hippopotamus will do.”) The ditty was, perhaps, unfamiliar to many listeners, but it penetrated the mind space of the unwary at warp speed — and stayed there. Resistance was futile.
